column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Posdnicheff was silent for a moment , and then resumed : —
#Text=“ After all , no !
#Text=It is better that things happened as they did , better ! ” he cried .
#Text=“ It was a good thing for me .
#Text=Besides , it makes no difference .
#Text=I was saying that in these cases it is the poor young girls who are deceived .

#Text=As for the mothers , the mothers especially , informed by their husbands , they know all , and , while pretending to believe in the purity of the young man , they act as if they did not believe in it .
#Text=“ They know what bait must be held out to people for themselves and their daughters .
#Text=We men sin through ignorance , and a determination not to learn .

#Text=As for the women , they know very well that the noblest and most poetic love , as we call it , depends , not on moral qualities , but on the physical intimacy , and also on the manner of doing the hair , and the color and shape .

#Text=“ Ask an experienced coquette , who has undertaken to seduce a man , which she would prefer , — to be convicted , in presence of the man whom she is engaged in conquering , of falsehood , perversity , cruelty , or to appear before him in an ill-fitting dress , or a dress of an unbecoming color .
#Text=She will prefer the first alternative .

#Text=She knows very well that we simply lie when we talk of our elevated sentiments , that we seek only the possession of her body , and that because of that we will forgive her every sort of baseness , but will not forgive her a costume of an ugly shade , without taste or fit .
#Text=“
#Text=And these things she knows by reason , where as the maiden knows them only by instinct , like the animal .
#Text=Hence these abominable jerseys , these artificial humps on the back , these bare shoulders , arms , and throats .

#Text=“ Women , especially those who have passed through the school of marriage , know very well that conversations upon elevated subjects are only conversations , and that man seeks and desires the body and all that ornaments the body .
#Text=Consequently , they act accordingly ?
#Text=If we reject conventional explanations , and view the life of our upper and lower classes as it is , with all its shamelessness , it is only a vast perversity .
#Text=You do not share this opinion ?
#Text=Permit me , I am going to prove it to you ( said he , interrupting me ) .
#Text=“ You say that the women of our society live for a different interest from that which actuates fallen women .
#Text=And I say no , and I am going to prove it to you .

#Text=If beings differ from one another according to the purpose of their life , according to their inner life , this will necessarily be reflected also in their outer life , and their exterior will be very different .

#Text=Well , then , compare the wretched , the despised , with the women of the highest society : the same dresses , the same fashions , the same perfumeries , the same passion for jewelry , for brilliant and very expensive articles , the same amusements , dances , music , and songs .
#Text=The former attract by all possible means ; so do the latter .
#Text=No difference , none whatever !
#Text=“
#Text=Yes , and I , too , was captivated by jerseys , bustles , and curly hair . ”
#Text=CHAPTER VII .
#Text=“ And it was very easy to capture me , since I was brought up under artificial conditions , like cucumbers in a hothouse .
#Text=Our too abundant nourishment , together with complete physical idleness , is nothing but systematic excitement of the imagination .
#Text=The men of our society are fed and kept like reproductive stallions .

#Text=It is sufficient to close the valve , — that is , for a young man to live a quiet life for some time , — to produce as an immediate result a restlessness , which , becoming exaggerated by reflection through the prism of our unnatural life , provokes the illusion of love .
#Text=“ All our idyls and marriage , all , are the result for the most part of our eating .
#Text=Does that astonish you ?
#Text=For my part , I am astonished that we do not see it .
#Text=Not far from my estate this spring some moujiks were working on a railway embankment .
#Text=You know what a peasant ’s food is , — bread , kvass , [ * ] onions .
#Text=With this frugal nourishment he lives , he is alert , he makes light work in the fields .
#Text=But on the railway this bill of fare becomes cacha and a pound of meat .
#Text=Only he restores this meat by sixteen hours of labor pushing loads weighing twelve hundred pounds .
#Text=[ * ]
#Text=Kvass , a sort of cider .
#Text=“
#Text=And we , who eat two pounds of meat and game , we who absorb all sorts of heating drinks and food , how do we expend it ?
#Text=In sensual excesses .

#Text=If the valve is open , all goes well ; but close it , as I had closed it temporarily before my marriage , and immediately there will result an excitement which , deformed by novels , verses , music , by our idle and luxurious life , will give a love of the finest water .
#Text=I , too , fell in love , as everybody does , and there were transports , emotions , poesy ; but really all this passion was prepared by mamma and the dressmakers .
#Text=If there had been no trips in boats , no well-fitted garments , etc. , if my wife had worn some shapeless blouse , and I had seen her thus at her home , I should not have been seduced . ”
#Text=CHAPTER VIII .
#Text=“ And note , also , this falsehood , of which all are guilty ; the way in which marriages are made .
#Text=What could there be more natural ?
#Text=The young girl is marriageable , she should marry .
#Text=What simpler , provided the young person is not a monster , and men can be found with a desire to marry ?
#Text=Well , no , here begins a new hypocrisy .
